sections.title: Reducing Your Tax Bill Legally
sections.subtitle: Understanding deductions, credits, and tax-saving strategies

sections.title: What You'll Learn
items: The difference between tax deductions and credits
Common deductions and how to maximize them
Tax credits that can significantly reduce your tax liability
Strategies for timing deductions and credits

sections.title: Deductions vs. Credits
sections.content: Tax deductions reduce your taxable income, while tax credits reduce your tax liability dollar-for-dollar. Credits are generally more valuable than deductions. For example, a $1,000 credit saves you $1,000 in taxes, while a $1,000 deduction only saves you $1,000 times your marginal tax rate.

points.title: Standard Deduction
points.description: A fixed amount you can deduct without itemizing ($13,850 for single filers in 2023).

points.title: Itemized Deductions
points.description: Medical expenses, state taxes, mortgage interest, charitable contributions - only if they exceed the standard deduction.

points.title: Above-the-Line Deductions
points.description: Retirement contributions, student loan interest, HSA contributions - deducted before calculating AGI.

sections.title: Bunching Strategy
sections.content: Combine multiple years of charitable contributions or medical expenses into one year to exceed the standard deduction threshold and maximize itemized deductions.

sections.title: Valuable Tax Credits
sections.content: Tax credits can dramatically reduce your tax bill. Common credits include the Child Tax Credit, Earned Income Tax Credit, education credits, and energy-efficient home improvement credits. These are especially valuable for lower and middle-income taxpayers.

sections.title: Maximize Your Tax Savings
steps: Track deductible expenses throughout the year using an app or spreadsheet
Maximize retirement contributions to reduce taxable income
Consider bunching charitable contributions every other year
Review eligibility for tax credits based on your family and financial situation

sections.title: Keep Good Records
sections.content: Maintain organized records of all deductible expenses and contributions throughout the year. This makes tax preparation easier and helps you identify all potential deductions.
